page.text: This report summarizes the findings of the Traffic Impact Analysis (TIA) that was prepared for the
ABB Manufacturing Facility, which is to be located on the east side of Meacham Farm Drive in
Huntersville, North Carolina. It is understood that the subject site will consist of a 248,276 square
foot manufacturing facility upon full build out in the year 2012. Access to the development is
proposed via a connection to existing Meacham Farm Drive.
The following table summarizes the trip generation for the proposed development.
It is estimated that the manufacturing facility will generate a total of 424 trips (in and out) during a
typical weekday. Of these average weekday trips, it is estimated that the development will
generate 115 trips (89 entering and 26 exiting) during the AM peak hour and 90 trips (27 entering
and 63 exiting) during the PM peak hour.
The purpose of this study is to determine the potential impacts to the surrounding transportation
system caused by the additional traffic generated by the proposed manufacturing facility. In order
to accomplish this objective, this study analyzed existing (2011) traffic conditions and future
(2012) traffic conditions under ‘no-build’ and ‘build’ scenarios during the weekday AM and PM
Under existing conditions, the northbound left turn movement from Old Statesville Road and the
southbound left turn movement from Statesville Road [onto Verhoeff Drive] experience minor
delays and operate at LOS A during the AM and PM peak hours. The eastbound stop-controlled
approach of Verhoeff Drive [at Old Statesville Road] experiences moderate overall delays and
operates at LOS D or better, while the westbound approach of Verhoeff Drive [at Statesville Road]
experiences greater delays and operates at LOS E and D during the AM and PM peak hours,
respectively. The southbound left turn movement from Old Statesville Road [onto Meacham
Farm Drive] experiences minor delays and operates at LOS A during the peak hours. The
westbound stop-controlled approach of Meacham Farm Drive [at Old Statesville Road]
experiences moderate overall delays and operates at LOS D or better. All intersections are
currently under capacity during the AM and PM peak hours that corresponds to the intersection’s
A major construction project is proposed within the study area, and is expected to be completed by
2012. A new bridge will be constructed over Old Statesville Road in the immediate vicinity of the
existing intersection of Old Statesville Road and Meacham Farm Drive, which will be eliminated.
New Verhoeff Drive will be extended over Old Statesville Road and loop around to form a new
three-legged unsignalized intersection with South Church Street. The existing intersection of Old
Statesville Road and Verhoeff Drive will remain, but Old Verhoeff Drive will be realigned to
intersect New Verhoeff Drive to form a new four-legged unsignalized intersection opposite the
Under background traffic conditions with the Verhoeff Drive project completed, the northbound
left turn movement from Old Statesville Road and the southbound left turn movement from
Statesville Road [onto Verhoeff Drive] are expected to experience minor delays and operate at
LOS A during the AM and PM peak hours. The eastbound stop-controlled approach of Old
Verhoeff Drive [at Old Statesville Road] is expected to experience moderate overall delays and
operate at LOS D or better, while the westbound approach of Verhoeff Drive [at Statesville Road]
is expected to experience greater delays and operate at LOS E and D during the AM and PM peak
hours, respectively. The poorer levels of operation on the stop-controlled approach is primarily a
result of the delays experienced by the left turn movement, which is not uncommon at
As for the two (2) new unsignalized intersections that will be created as part of the Verhoeff Drive
project, the eastbound and westbound left turn movements from New Verhoeff Drive [onto Old
Verhoeff Drive and into CPCC] are expected to experience minor delays and operate at LOS A
during the peak hours. The northbound and southbound stop-controlled approaches of CPCC and
New Verhoeff Drive are expected to experience minor to moderate overall delays and operate at
LOS B or better. The southbound left turn movement from South Church Street [onto New
Verhoeff Drive] is expected to experience minor delays and operate at LOS A during the peak
hours. The westbound stop-controlled approach of New Verhoeff Drive is expected to experience
minor overall delays and operate at LOS A.
All intersections are expected to have additional capacity during the peak hours.
Under combined traffic conditions, the northbound left turn movement from Old Statesville Road
and the southbound left turn movement from Statesville Road [onto Verhoeff Drive] are expected
to experience minor to moderate delays and operate at LOS B or better during the AM and PM
peak hours. The eastbound stop-controlled approach of Old Verhoeff Drive [at Old Statesville
Road] is expected to experience greater overall delays and operate at LOS D and E during the AM
and PM peak hours, respectively. The westbound approach of Verhoeff Drive [at Statesville
Road] is expected to experience greater delays and operate at LOS F and D during the AM and PM
peak hours, respectively. The poorer levels of operation on the stop-controlled approaches is
primarily a result of the delays experienced by the left turn movement, which is not uncommon at
As for the new unsignalized intersections, the eastbound and westbound left turn movements from
New Verhoeff Drive [onto Old Verhoeff Drive and into CPCC] are expected to experience minor
delays and operate at LOS A during the peak hours. The northbound and southbound stop-
controlled approaches of CPCC and New Verhoeff Drive are expected to experience minor to
moderate overall delays and operate at LOS C or better. The southbound left turn movement from
South Church Street [onto New Verhoeff Drive] is expected to experience minor delays and
operate at LOS A during the peak hours. The westbound stop-controlled approach of New
Verhoeff Drive is expected to experience minor overall delays and operate at LOS A.
All intersections are expected to have additional capacity during the peak hours.
In addition to the Synchro analysis, a traffic simulation model was developed utilizing SimTraffic
to evaluate the queuing conditions at the study intersections. Based on the maximum queues, the
existing and proposed storage lengths for the auxiliary turn lanes should accommodate the
In conclusion, the traffic generated by the ABB Manufacturing Facility is not expected to have a
significant impact to the surrounding transportation. With the improvements provided under the
Verhoeff Drive project, the intersections and auxiliary turn lanes are expected to accommodate the
additional traffic. While the stop-controlled approaches of Verhoeff Drive [at Statesville Road
and New Verhoeff Drive] could be expected to experience poorer overall levels of operation due
to the left turn movement delays, no improvements are recommended since exclusive left and right
turn lanes are [or will be] provided on the approaches at both unsignalized intersections.
Furthermore, the greater delays anticipated for the stop-controlled approaches are not an
uncommon occurrence at unsignalized intersections located on major thoroughfares and are
nearing levels of operation of E or F under background traffic conditions.
1.2. Proposed Land Use and Site Access
3.1. Analysis of Existing (2011) Peak Hour Traffic
4.3. Analysis of Background Peak Hour Traffic
5.3. Analysis of Combined Peak Hour Traffic
HCM Levels of Service and Delay
Table 1A Synchro Intersection Capacity Utilization and Levels of Service
Background (2012) Traffic Conditions with Traffic Adjustments
Capacity Analysis Reports – Existing (2011) Traffic Conditions
Capacity Analysis Reports – Background (2012) Traffic Conditions
Capacity Analysis & Queuing Reports – Combined (2012) Traffic Conditions
This report summarizes the findings of the Traffic Impact Analysis (TIA) that was prepared for the
ABB Manufacturing Facility, which is to be located on the east side of Meacham Farm Drive in
Huntersville, North Carolina. It is understood that the subject site will consist of a 248,276 square
foot manufacturing facility upon full build out. The purpose of this study is to determine the
potential impacts to the surrounding transportation system caused by the additional traffic
generated by the proposed manufacturing facility. In order to accomplish this objective, this study
analyzed existing (2011) traffic conditions and future (2012) traffic conditions under ‘no-build’
and ‘build’ scenarios during the weekday AM and PM peak hours.
The site is located on the east side of existing Meacham Farm Drive in Huntersville, North
Carolina. Refer to Figure 1 for the site location map. The study area was developed through
coordination with the Town of Huntersville and the North Carolina Department of Transportation
(NCDOT) and consists of the following intersections:
1. Statesville Road (US 21) and Verhoeff Drive - Unsignalized
2. Old Statesville Road (NC 115) and Verhoeff Drive - Unsignalized
3. Old Statesville Road (NC 115) and Meacham Farm Drive - Unsignalized to be Eliminated
4. New Verhoeff Drive and Old Verhoeff Drive – Future Unsignalized
5. South Church Street and New Verhoeff Drive – Future Unsignalized
Refer to Appendix A for a copy of the Scoping Package that was approved by the Town of

text.b: 1.2. Proposed Land Use and Site Access

page.text: The site will consist of a 248,276 square foot manufacturing facility. It is understood that the
development will be fully built out by the year 2012. Access to the development is proposed via a
connection to existing Meacham Farm Drive. Refer to Figure 2 for an illustration of the site plan.
Land use within the immediate vicinity of the site consists of residential, industrial, and
educational uses. Central Piedmont Community College is located on the south side of Verhoeff
Drive, while Lake Norman Charter School is located on the west side of Old Statesville Road. It
was determined through coordination with the Town of Huntersville that there were no adjacent
developments that needed to be incorporated into the future year analysis.
The project study area for this TIA consists of the following facilities: Statesville Road (US 21),
Old Statesville Road (NC 115), and Verhoeff Drive NC 73. Statesville Road (US 21) and Old
Statesville Road (NC 115) are both major north-south thoroughfares while Verhoeff Drive is a
minor east-west thoroughfare. Statesville Road is a two-lane facility with a posted speed limit of
50 miles per hour (mph). Exclusive left and right turn lanes exist on Statesville Road at the
intersection with Verhoeff Drive. Old Statesville Road is a two-lane facility with a posted speed
limit of 35 mph north of the intersection with Verhoeff Drive, and 45 mph south of Verhoeff
Drive. Verhoeff Drive is a two-lane facility with a posted speed limit of 35 mph. Exclusive left
and right turn lanes exist on Verhoeff Drive at the intersection with Statesville Road. According
to 2008 NCDOT Annual Average Daily Traffic (AADT) data, which is the most recent available,
Statesville Road carries 11,000 vehicles per day (vpd) [south of Verhoeff Drive], Old Statesville
Road carries 9,800 vpd [south of Verhoeff Drive], and Verhoeff Drive carries 5,000 vpd.
Existing lane configurations (number of traffic lanes on the intersection approach), lane widths,
storage capacities, and other intersection and roadway information was collected through field
reconnaissance by Ramey Kemp & Associates, Inc. (RKA). Refer to Figure 3 for an illustration
of the existing lane configurations and traffic control conditions.
All intersection capacity analyses were completed using Synchro 7. Synchro is a comprehensive
software package that allows the user to model and analyze unsignalized intersections utilizing the
methodologies outlined in the 2000 Highway Capacity Manual. Analysis results for unsignalized
intersections do not provide an overall level of service, but rather a level of service for movements
and/or approaches that have a conflicting movement.
The HCM defines capacity as “the maximum hourly rate at which persons or vehicles can
reasonably be expected to traverse a point or uniform section of a lane or roadway during a given
time period under prevailing roadway, traffic, and control conditions”. Level of service (LOS) is a
term used to represent different driving conditions, and is defined as a “qualitative measure
describing operational conditions within a traffic stream, and their perception by motorists and/or
passengers”. Level of service varies from Level “A” representing free flow, to Level “F” where
greater vehicle delays are evident. Refer to Table 1 for HCM levels of service and related average
control delay per vehicle for unsignalized intersections. Control delay as defined by the HCM
includes “initial deceleration delay, queue move-up time, stopped delay, and final acceleration
delay”. As shown in Table 1, levels of service are stated in terms of average control delay. An
average control delay of 30 seconds at an unsignalized intersection results in level of service D
HIGHWAY CAPACITY MANUAL LEVELS OF SERVICE AND DELAY
The Intersection Capacity Utilization (ICU) measures the amount of capacity that is available at a
signalized intersection. As for unsignalized intersections, the ICU represents the potential
capacity if the intersection were signalized. Level of service varies from Level “A” representing
uncongested conditions and additional capacity, to Level “H” where the intersection is over
capacity and congested conditions are evident. Refer to Table 1A for ICU levels of service and
related intersection capacity utilization. As shown in Table 1A, an intersection capacity
utilization of 75% results in level of service (LOS) D at the intersection. The baseline for this
SYNCHRO INTERSECTION CAPACITY UTILIZATION AND LEVELS OF SERVICE
Existing weekday AM and PM peak hour traffic volumes for the study intersections were obtained
from turning movement counts conducted by RKA on February 24, 2011 during the AM (7:00 to
9:00) and PM (4:30 to 6:30) peak periods. Refer to Figure 4 for an illustration of the existing peak
hour traffic volumes. Please note that the traffic volumes were balanced upwards between the
intersections of Verhoeff Drive and Meacham Farm Drive on Old Statesville Road. In addition,
the traffic volumes were balanced on Verhoeff Drive [between the Central Piedmont Community
College Access and Old Statesville Road] and Meacham Farm Drive [between Old Statesville
Road and South Church Street]. A copy of the raw traffic count data can be found in Appendix B

text.b: 3.1. Analysis of Existing (2011) Peak Hour Traffic

page.text: In order to estimate the current operating levels of service (LOS) at the study intersections, the
existing (2011) traffic volumes were analyzed under existing lane configurations and traffic
control conditions. The capacity analysis results are presented in Table 2. Refer to Appendix C
for more detailed capacity analysis results.
Level of service for left turn movement on major approach.
Capacity analysis indicates that the northbound left turn movement from Old Statesville Road and
the southbound left turn movement from Statesville Road [onto Verhoeff Drive] experience minor
delays of less than 10 seconds per vehicle and operate at LOS A during the AM and PM peak
hours. The eastbound stop-controlled approach of Verhoeff Drive [at Old Statesville Road]
experiences moderate overall delays of 32 seconds per vehicle or less and operates at LOS D or
better, while the westbound approach of Verhoeff Drive [at Statesville Road] experiences greater
delays of 39 seconds per vehicle or less and operates at LOS E and D during the AM and PM peak
hours, respectively. Both intersections are currently under capacity based on the ICU LOS D or
better, which corresponds to the intersection’s capacity under signalized conditions.
Analysis indicates that the southbound left turn movement from Old Statesville Road [onto
Meacham Farm Drive] experiences minor delays of less than a second per vehicle and operates at
LOS A during the AM and PM peak hours. The westbound stop-controlled approach of Meacham
Farm Drive [at Old Statesville Road] experiences moderate overall delays of approximately 30
seconds per vehicle or less and operates at LOS D or better. This intersection is currently under
capacity based on the ICU LOS B or better, which corresponds to the intersection’s capacity under
In order to account for the growth of traffic and subsequent traffic conditions at a future year,
background traffic projections are needed. Background traffic is that component of traffic due to
growth of the community and surrounding area that is anticipated to occur regardless of whether
To account for the growth of ‘background’ traffic that is anticipated regardless of site
development, the existing traffic volumes within the study area were projected to the year 2012 by
applying an annual growth rate of 2%. Refer to Figure 5 for an illustration of the background
A major construction project is proposed within the study area, and is expected to be completed by
2012. A new bridge will be constructed over Old Statesville Road in the immediate vicinity of the
existing intersection of Old Statesville Road and Meacham Farm Drive, which will be eliminated.
New Verhoeff Drive will be extended over Old Statesville Road and loop around to form a new
three-legged unsignalized intersection with South Church Street. The existing intersection of Old
Statesville Road and Verhoeff Drive will remain, but Old Verhoeff Drive will be realigned to
intersect New Verhoeff Drive to form a new four-legged unsignalized intersection opposite the
realigned access to CPCC. Refer to Figure 6 for an illustration of the future lane configurations.
A copy of the roadway plans can be found in Appendix D.
The Verhoeff Drive project will have a significant effect on the existing travel patterns. In order
to analyze the future ‘no-build’ traffic conditions, adjustments had to be made to the existing
traffic patterns. Refer to Figures 7 and 8 for an illustration of the traffic adjustments associated
the Verhoeff Drive project and the adjusted background peak hour traffic volumes, respectively.

text.b: Analysis of Background Peak Hour Traffic

page.text: The study intersections were analyzed under future lane configurations (Figure 6) and traffic
control conditions. A summary of the capacity analysis results are presented in Table 3. Refer to
Appendix E for more detailed capacity analysis results.
Underline denotes Verhoeff Drive Project Improvements
Level of service for left turn movement on major approach.
Capacity analysis indicates that the northbound left turn movement from Old Statesville Road and
the southbound left turn movement from Statesville Road [onto Verhoeff Drive] are expected to
experience minor delays of 10 seconds per vehicle or less and operate at LOS A during the AM
and PM peak hours. The eastbound stop-controlled approach of Old Verhoeff Drive [at Old
Statesville Road] is expected to experience moderate overall delays of 29 seconds per vehicle or
less and operate at LOS D or better, while the westbound approach of Verhoeff Drive [at
Statesville Road] is expected to experience greater delays of 43 seconds per vehicle or less and
operate at LOS E and D during the AM and PM peak hours, respectively. The poorer levels of
operation on the stop-controlled approach is primarily a result of the delays experienced by the left
turn movement, which is not uncommon at unsignalized intersections. Both intersections are
expected to be under capacity based on the ICU LOS A.
As previously discussed in Section 4.2 (Future Roadway Improvements), two (2) new
unsignalized intersections will be created as part of the Verhoeff Drive project: 1) New Verhoeff
Drive and Old Verhoeff Drive/CPCC and 2) South Church Street and New Verhoeff Drive.
Capacity analysis indicates that the eastbound and westbound left turn movements from New
Verhoeff Drive [onto Old Verhoeff Drive and into CPCC] are expected to experience minor
delays of 8 seconds per vehicle or less and operate at LOS A during the AM and PM peak hours.
The northbound and southbound stop-controlled approaches of CPCC and New Verhoeff Drive
are expected to experience minor to moderate overall delays of 15 seconds per vehicle or less and
operate at LOS B or better. As for the intersection of South Church Street and New Verhoeff
Drive, analysis indicates that the southbound left turn movement from South Church Street [onto
New Verhoeff Drive] is expected to experience minor delays of 8 seconds per vehicle or less and
operate at LOS A during the AM and PM peak hours. The westbound stop-controlled approach of
New Verhoeff Drive is expected to experience minor overall delays of approximately 9 seconds
per vehicle or less and operate at LOS A. Based on the ICU LOS A, both intersections are
In order to estimate future traffic conditions with the proposed manufacturing facility constructed,
traffic was generated and combined with the projected ‘background’ traffic volumes.
Average weekday daily and AM and PM peak hour trips were calculated based on hourly
employee and truck traffic projections (refer to Appendix F for a copy of the spreadsheet data).
The data was provided by ABB, Inc. and approved by the Town of Huntersville. Refer to Table 4
for a detailed breakdown of the trip generation results.
It is estimated that the manufacturing facility will generate a total of 424 trips (in and out) during a
typical weekday. Of these average weekday trips, it is estimated that the development will
generate 115 trips (89 entering and 26 exiting) during the AM peak hour [of which 3 trucks would
enter the facility] and 90 trips (27 entering and 63 exiting) during the PM peak hour [of which 1
truck would enter and 2 trucks would exit the facility].
For this study, trip distribution percentages were developed through coordination with the Town
of Huntersville and NCDOT. It is estimated that traffic will access the manufacturing facility
 35% to/from the north via Statesville Road (US 21)
 25% to/from the north via Old Statesville Road (NC 115)
 40% to/from the south via Old Statesville Road (NC 115)
Refer to Figure 9 for an illustration of the site trip distribution. The site trip assignment is

text.b: Analysis of Combined Peak Hour Traffic

page.text: As previously indicated, the site-generated traffic was added to the ‘background’ traffic volumes
to determine combined traffic conditions. Refer to Figure 11 for an illustration of combined peak
hour traffic volumes. The study intersections were analyzed with the combined traffic volumes
using the same methodology previously discussed for the background traffic conditions. A
summary of the capacity analysis results is presented in Table 5. Refer to Appendix G for more
Underline denotes Verhoeff Drive Project Improvements
Level of service for left turn movement on major approach.
Capacity analysis indicates that the northbound left turn movement from Old Statesville Road and
the southbound left turn movement from Statesville Road [onto Verhoeff Drive] are expected to
experience minor to moderate delays of 11 seconds per vehicle or less and operate at LOS B or
better during the AM and PM peak hours. The eastbound stop-controlled approach of Old
Verhoeff Drive [at Old Statesville Road] is expected to experiences greater overall delays of 36
seconds per vehicle or less and operate at LOS D and E during the AM and PM peak hours,
respectively. The westbound approach of Verhoeff Drive [at Statesville Road] is expected to
experience greater delays of 52 seconds per vehicle or less and operate at LOS F and D during the
AM and PM peak hours, respectively. The poorer levels of operation on the stop-controlled
approaches is primarily a result of the delays experienced by the left turn movement, which is not
uncommon at unsignalized intersections. Both intersections are expected to be under capacity
based on the ICU LOS A.
As for the new unsignalized intersections, analysis indicates that the eastbound and westbound left
turn movements from New Verhoeff Drive [onto Old Verhoeff Drive and into CPCC] are expected
to experience minor delays of 8 seconds per vehicle or less and operate at LOS A during the AM
and PM peak hours. The northbound and southbound stop-controlled approaches of CPCC and
New Verhoeff Drive are expected to experience minor to moderate overall delays of 16 seconds
per vehicle or less and operate at LOS C or better. Capacity analysis indicates that the southbound
left turn movement from South Church Street [onto New Verhoeff Drive] is expected to
experience minor delays of 8 seconds per vehicle or less and operate at LOS A during the AM and
PM peak hours. The westbound stop-controlled approach of New Verhoeff Drive is expected to
experience minor overall delays of 10 seconds per vehicle or less and operate at LOS A. Based on
the ICU LOS A, both intersections are expected to be under capacity.
In addition to the Synchro analysis, a traffic simulation model was developed utilizing SimTraffic
to evaluate the queuing conditions at the study intersections. All queuing results were based on an
average of ten (10) simulation runs. Refer to Appendix G for more detailed SimTraffic queuing
results. In addition, the storage lengths were evaluated using the NCDOT Warrants for Left and
Right Turn Lanes in the “Policy On Street And Driveway Access to North Carolina Highways –
July 2003 Edition”. The existing and proposed storage lengths for the auxiliary turn lanes should
accommodate the projected turning movements based on the queues illustrated in Figure 12.
This traffic impact analysis was performed to determine potential traffic impacts caused by the
additional traffic generated by the subject site. It is understood that the site will consist of a
248,276 square foot manufacturing facility, and will be fully built out by the year 2012. In
addition to site-generated traffic, the study also considered the impact of background traffic
Under existing conditions, the northbound left turn movement from Old Statesville Road and the
southbound left turn movement from Statesville Road [onto Verhoeff Drive] experience minor
delays and operate at LOS A during the AM and PM peak hours. The eastbound stop-controlled
approach of Verhoeff Drive [at Old Statesville Road] experiences moderate overall delays and
operates at LOS D or better, while the westbound approach of Verhoeff Drive [at Statesville
Road] experiences greater delays and operates at LOS E and D during the AM and PM peak
hours, respectively. The southbound left turn movement from Old Statesville Road [onto
Meacham Farm Drive] experiences minor delays and operates at LOS A during the peak hours.
The westbound stop-controlled approach of Meacham Farm Drive [at Old Statesville Road]
experiences moderate overall delays and operates at LOS D or better. All intersections are
currently under capacity during the AM and PM peak hours that corresponds to the intersection’s
A major construction project is proposed within the study area, and is expected to be completed by
2012. A new bridge will be constructed over Old Statesville Road in the immediate vicinity of the
existing intersection of Old Statesville Road and Meacham Farm Drive, which will be eliminated.
New Verhoeff Drive will be extended over Old Statesville Road and loop around to form a new
three-legged unsignalized intersection with South Church Street. The existing intersection of Old
Statesville Road and Verhoeff Drive will remain, but Old Verhoeff Drive will be realigned to
intersect New Verhoeff Drive to form a new four-legged unsignalized intersection opposite the
Under background traffic conditions with the Verhoeff Drive project completed, the northbound
left turn movement from Old Statesville Road and the southbound left turn movement from
Statesville Road [onto Verhoeff Drive] are expected to experience minor delays and operate at
LOS A during the AM and PM peak hours. The eastbound stop-controlled approach of Old
Verhoeff Drive [at Old Statesville Road] is expected to experience moderate overall delays and
operate at LOS D or better, while the westbound approach of Verhoeff Drive [at Statesville Road]
is expected to experience greater delays and operate at LOS E and D during the AM and PM peak
hours, respectively. The poorer levels of operation on the stop-controlled approach is primarily a
result of the delays experienced by the left turn movement, which is not uncommon at
As for the two (2) new unsignalized intersections that will be created as part of the Verhoeff Drive
project, the eastbound and westbound left turn movements from New Verhoeff Drive [onto Old
Verhoeff Drive and into CPCC] are expected to experience minor delays and operate at LOS A
during the peak hours. The northbound and southbound stop-controlled approaches of CPCC and
New Verhoeff Drive are expected to experience minor to moderate overall delays and operate at
LOS B or better. The southbound left turn movement from South Church Street [onto New
Verhoeff Drive] is expected to experience minor delays and operate at LOS A during the peak
hours. The westbound stop-controlled approach of New Verhoeff Drive is expected to experience
minor overall delays and operate at LOS A.
All intersections are expected to have additional capacity during the peak hours.
Under combined traffic conditions, the northbound left turn movement from Old Statesville Road
and the southbound left turn movement from Statesville Road [onto Verhoeff Drive] are expected
to experience minor to moderate delays and operate at LOS B or better during the AM and PM
peak hours. The eastbound stop-controlled approach of Old Verhoeff Drive [at Old Statesville
Road] is expected to experience greater overall delays and operate at LOS D and E during the AM
and PM peak hours, respectively. The westbound approach of Verhoeff Drive [at Statesville
is expected to experience greater delays and operate at LOS F and D during the AM and PM peak
hours, respectively. The poorer levels of operation on the stop-controlled approaches is primarily
a result of the delays experienced by the left turn movement, which is not uncommon at
As for the new unsignalized intersections, the eastbound and westbound left turn movements from
New Verhoeff Drive [onto Old Verhoeff Drive and into CPCC] are expected to experience minor
delays and operate at LOS A during the peak hours. The northbound and southbound stop-
controlled approaches of CPCC and New Verhoeff Drive are expected to experience minor to
moderate overall delays and operate at LOS C or better. The southbound left turn movement from
South Church Street [onto New Verhoeff Drive] is expected to experience minor delays and
operate at LOS A during the peak hours. The westbound stop-controlled approach of New
Verhoeff Drive is expected to experience minor overall delays and operate at LOS A.
All intersections are expected to have additional capacity during the peak hours.
In addition to the Synchro analysis, a traffic simulation model was developed utilizing SimTraffic
to evaluate the queuing conditions at the study intersections. Based on the maximum queues, the
existing and proposed storage lengths for the auxiliary turn lanes should accommodate the
In conclusion, the traffic generated by the ABB Manufacturing Facility is not expected to have a
significant impact to the surrounding transportation. With the improvements provided under the
Verhoeff Drive project, the intersections and auxiliary turn lanes are expected to accommodate the
additional traffic. While the stop-controlled approaches of Verhoeff Drive [at Statesville Road
and New Verhoeff Drive] could be expected to experience poorer overall levels of operation due
to the left turn movement delays, no improvements are recommended since exclusive left and right
turn lanes are [or will be] provided on the approaches at both unsignalized intersections.
Furthermore, the greater delays anticipated for the stop-controlled approaches are not an
uncommon occurrence at unsignalized intersections located on major thoroughfares and are
nearing levels of operation of E or F under background traffic conditions.
Per our meeting on February 18, 2011 and the supplemental traffic data that was collected at the
intersection of US 21 and Verhoeff Drove, the scoping package was revised for the ABB
Manufacturing Facility. The revised scoping package was prepared in accordance with the Town of
Huntersville’s Traffic Impact Analysis (TIA) Process and Procedures Manual (dated July 2009).
The following information is included with the Scoping Package:
Site Trip Generation: Daily (424 vpd), AM (89 entering/26 exiting), PM (27 entering/63 exiting)
In addition to the attached information, we would like to provide the following information in
regards to the study area and analysis period. It is assumed that the study area will consist of the
Old Statesville Road (NC 115) and Verhoeff Drive
Old Statesville Road (NC 115) and Meacham Farm Drive (Intersection to be Eliminated)
New Verhoeff Drive and Old Verhoeff Drive (New Intersection)
South Church Street and New Verhoeff Drive (New Intersection)
The development is not anticipated to contribute 7% or more of the traffic on any approach of
nearby intersections on Old Statesville Road (NC 115) at Gilead Road and Alexanderana Road (see
attached). The proposed manufacturing facility is proposed to be fully operational by the year 2012;
therefore, the horizon year for the TIA is proposed to be the year 2012. In order to account for
future background growth that is anticipated to occur within the community and surrounding areas, a
compounded annual growth rate of 2% is proposed to be utilized to estimate future (2012) peak hour
traffic volumes at the study intersections. Furthermore, it is understood that there are currently no
approved developments that are anticipated to have a significant impact on the study area.
If you should have any questions, or comments, relative to this correspondence, please feel free to
Jayson B. Clapp, Jr., P.E., PTOE
